entry.title: Understanding Release Contracts (C0–C3) in S/4HANA Repository Objects
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog is the first in a short series about extension and API stability in S/4HANA. In this post I’ll explain release contracts (also known as stability contracts) — what they are, why SAP uses them, and how they affect the objects you work with every day.

A Release Contract is a classification that indicates how stable a repository object is and how it can be used or extended. It’s SAP’s formal promise that certain objects will remain stable across upgrades. The goal is to strike a balance: on one hand, SAP keeps the system flexible so development can continue; on the other, key technical elements are kept stable so consumers don’t need to rewrite code after every upgrade.

To provide those guarantees, SAP defines different stability/release contracts (C0, C1, C2, …). Each contract describes the intended scope of use — for example, whether something is intended as a safe extension point, a stable in-system API, or a remote API for external callers.

Stability Contracts

       C0 : Contract for Extensions

       C1 : Contract for System Internal Use

       C2 : Contract for Remote API Use

       C3 : Manage Configuration Content

       C4 : Use in ABAP Managed Database Procedure ( Not covered in this blog )

Let us look at how these Contracts apply to comman repository Objects.

CDS Views : CDS views are one of the most common repository objects you’ll come across in S/4HANA. SAP uses release contracts to make clear whether a CDS view can be extended, consumed inside the system, or even exposed to the outside world.

  • C0 - Extend

    • A C0 contract means the CDS view can be safely extended
    • There are two main ways to extend
      • Key user Extensibility : add your own custom fields (or sometimes even make standard fields available) using the Custom Fields app in FIORI.
      • Developer Extensibility : Use ABAP Development Tools (ADT) to create a CDS view extension. This lets you add fields or annotations to the view in a controlled way.
    • The promise here is that the structure of the view won’t change in a way that breaks your code across upgrades.

            

  • C1 - System Internal Use

    • A C1 contract means the CDS view is a stable API for internal consumption.

    • You can safely use a C1 released CDS in :
      • Key user Extensibility : For Analytical Queries, Custom CDS Views
      • Developer Extensibility : In Custom ABAP code in ABAP Cloud or S/4 HANA Cloud.
    • In both cases, the base CDS view provides stable “anchors” where your extensions will survive upgrades.

          

  • C2 - Remote APIs

    • Sometimes the data in a CDS view isn’t just needed internally, but also by external systems.

    • In those cases, SAP exposes the CDS via an OData service (or other service binding).
    • When a CDS view is published for remote consumption, it carries a C2 contract. This ensures the external API is technically stable for side-by-side or third-party integrations.

                

 

Database Tables : Database tables are the lowest-level repository objects in the system. In Practice SAP most often delivers these with C3 ( Manage Configuration Content ).

Tables can also be prepared by the provider for C0 ( Developer Extensibility ) using specific Annotation and release state settings - but this is an opt-in decision design. Most standard tables are not exposed this way , because SAP prefers that extensions happen via CDS views.

The release contract you’ll find for tables is C3 – Manage Configuration Content.

  • C3 - Manage Configuration Content

    • A C3 contract means the table is intended for storing configuration data (for example, customizing or setup values).
    • With C3, SAP promises that the persistence and structure of the table will remain stable so that tools can reliably export, import, or transport configuration across systems.
  • Why Not C0 or C1 for tables ?
    • No C1: Tables are not meant to be consumed directly in ABAP Cloud development. If you need business data, you should always go through a released CDS view
    • C0 possible but rare : SAP does allow tables to be released with C0 if explicitly enabled by the provider (using annotations), but most delivered tables are not. Instead, SAP recommends CDS views or the Custom Fields app for extensibility. 

          

 

Behavior Defination ( RAP Business Object ) : Behavior definitions describe what you can do with a business object in RAP (the RESTful ABAP Programming Model) — things like creating, updating, deleting, running validations, or triggering actions. 

Unlike CDS views, most SAP-delivered behavior definitions are released with C1 (System-Internal Use). A C0 contract for behavior definitions is technically possible (the framework supports it if the provider enables extension anchors), but in practice it is rare. You should always check the API State in ADT to see what’s allowed.

  • C1 - System Internal Use

    • A C1 contract means the business object is safe to consume inside the system, but not open for developer extensions. 
    • You Can :
      • Call the BO’s actions and operations in your own ABAP Cloud code.
      • Bind the BO to a Fiori Elements app and use it in your custom applications.
      • Rely on its structure to remain stable across upgrades.

 

Conclusion

This blog focused on SAP-delivered objects and how SAP marks their stability (C0–C3): CDS views (C0 for extension, C1 for in-system use, C2 for remote APIs), behavior definitions (generally C1 for consumption; C0 only if explicitly enabled), and database tables (commonly C3 for configuration; tables can also be prepared for C0, but that is opt-in).. Although there are other blogs that go deep into specific object types, this post is meant as a pre-read to give you the holistic view. And if you want to actually find released objects and their contracts, the magic lies in the System Library in ADT — and how you configure the tree.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA for Group Reporting - Introducing New Rules for Automatic Postings
entry.content:
The new rules for automatic postings gradually replace existing functions such as net income calculations and reclassifications. These posting rules offer more capabilities, greater flexibility, and a modern user interface.

The following examples highlight the flexibility of the new rules:

  • Define source data flexibly, including field selections and period interval 
  • Assign multiple document types in one task
  • Include multiple posting lines
  • Define target data flexibly, including field assignment using attributes, and value calculation formula
  • Include results from previous rules
  • Use an enhanced partner filter for intra-unit eliminations.
  • Use the field assignment option 'Value Of ' to post on partner fields

-
Scenarios

With the rules for automatic postings, you can automate tasks such as:

  • Net income calculation for reported data while maintaining the same document type as the source data, and  also the original profit center or segment.
  • Reclassification of the inventory of finished goods to the inventory of semi-finished goods for manufacturing consolidation units.
  • Elimination of the inter-unit sales (reported by the selling consolidation unit) against the cost of sales in the partner unit (the buying consolidation unit).
  • Elimination of inter-unit receivables and payables against a balancing FS item to analyze the intercompany difference.
  • Elimination of intra-unit operations reported between different profit centers within one consolidation unit.

-
Components

Components

  1. When you run a task from the data or consolidation monitor, the system runs all the posting rules included in the rule group assigned to the task.
  2. Each rule selects source data and posts one or more posting lines. The rule automatically assigns the field values and calculates the amounts to post.
  3. The system creates a log that includes source lines, posting lines and any warning or error messages.

Use the following three new apps to manage the posting rules:

 

Rule Definition

Watch this video for guidance on defining a posting rule to calcule the net income:

 

Rule Type

You define a rule with one of the following rule types:

  • Net Income Calculation
  • Postings for Consolidation Units
  • Postings for Consolidation Unit Pairs

The type determines which options are available or required. The rule type also determines the monitor (Data Monitor, Consolidation Monitor) where the rules can be carried out.

Examples: 

  • A posting rule that was defined with rule type Postings for Consolidation Unit Pairs requires the Partner Units filter, and can be assigned to a task only in the Consolidation Monitor.
  • The option Post on Original Document Type is available only for the rule type Net Income Calculation.

Source Data

In this section, you define how the rule selects data. You can use:

  • A Selection defined in the Define Selections app.
  • A Period Selection, such as Year to Date, Prior Period, or Opening Balances.
  • Specific fields to include or exclude when reading data. Excluded fields are aggregated, improving the performance and the readibility of the log. 

Note: The values for Period, Year, Version, Consolidation Unit aren't aggregated.

Example: Only the fields Profit Center and Segment are read in the screenshot below. Details of other fields such as Cost Center aren't retained, and source values are aggregated.

  • You use the "Partner Units" option for elimination rules. In most scenarios you select the option "Partners in the Consolidation Group" . If the source data doesn't include a Partner Unit, you can select "All Partners (including empty)".

Example: Use this option to eliminate business operations between profit centers within a single Consolidation Unit, where there is no partner unit breakdown.

 

Target Data

In this section you define the measures (local currency, transaction currency, group currency, quantity) and document types for the postings. The available document types depend on the rule type. 

By selecting the document type in the rule you can group multiple automatic postings with different document types into a single task. This approach reduces the number of tasks you need to manage.

Example: You can define different rules for inter unit eliminations, such as sales and cost of sales, receivables and payables, or dividends. You can then group these rules into one single task and then post on different document types .

Posting Lines

Each rule must include at least one posting line, and can include multiple ones. To create a balanced posting, you need at least two posting lines. The number of posting lines doesn't determine the number of line items that will be posted. The number of line items depends on the granularity of the source data.

Example: If you define a rule with two posting lines to eliminate the internal sales FS item (posting line 1) against the cost of sales FS item (posting line 2), and your source data is broken down by segment and profit center, it include many lines. The rule will post for two posting lines for each source line.

Overview

In this overview you can create, display, delete, and sort posting lines.

Posting lines define how the source data is adjusted before posting. You can for instance assign a specific FS Item, clear the Material Number, or post to the Partner Unit.

Note: The posting line number is displayed in the log that is created when you run the task. This helps you to easily relate the posting line in the rule definition to the log entry.

Field Assignments

There are different ways to change the field values depending on the field. For FS items, you can assign values using attributes such as role and target attributes.  You can also select or clear a value, or post to the corresponding partner field. If you don't define a specific assignment for a field, the source value is kept.

In the example below the rule swaps the unit and partner fields for consolidation unit and profit center, assigns the functional area YB18 only when it is empty in the source data, and posts the FS item that is the target elimination of the source FS item.

Value Calculation

The value calculation determines the value to post on the measures selected for the target data.

You can use the following:

  • Mathematical operators: + - / * ( ) 
  • Constants: A number
  • Variables: Keyword SOURCE for the source amounts

Rule group

Watch this video to learn how to define a rule group:

 

In a rule group you select the rules to be carried out when you run the automatic postings task.

You can create nodes and subnodes to organize the rule group. For example:

  • Rules for net income calculation and reclassification of inventory of finished goods

 

  • Rules for inter-unit eliminations

 

 

In some scenarios you need to define that one rule "Depends on Previous Rules". This is necessary when the source data for the current rule includes data posted by the previous rule. When you select this option, the system updates the sequence column to show the order of processing.

Assign Rule Group

Once the rule group is defined with all the rules, assign it to the task using the app Assign Rule Groups for Automatic Postings.

You can define this assignment on several criteria:

  • Version: Depending on the configuration of the versions, the assignment can be valid for multiple versions. For example you can define an elimination task that carries out only the profit and loss eliminations for the planning versions, and all eliminations for actuals versions.
  • Time: Valid from Period / Year
  • Consolidation Units: For automatic postings tasks in the data monitor, you can restrict the assignment to selected consolidation units
  • Periods: you can restrict the assignment to certain periods. This allows one task to carry out different rule groups for a monthly (periods 1-11) or for a yearly consolidation (period 12).

Automatic Postings Run and Log

Watch this video to learn how to run a task for automatic postings and display the log:

 

You can change the log layout by selecting fields to display, and by defining grouping and sorting options.

The following fields help you analyze the log:

  • Item Type: Indicates whether the line is a source line or a posting line
  • Rule: The name of the rule that created the automatic posting
  • Posted Line: The number of the posting line defined in the rule
  • Source amounts and Posted amounts

-

entry.title: How SAP’s ABAP Cloud Partner Reference App Simplifies Multi-Tenant Side-by-Side Extensions on BTP
entry.content:
The SAP BTP ABAP environment continues to unlock powerful opportunities for partners and developers seeking to extend and integrate with SAP Cloud ERP - particularly SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, by enabling SaaS extension development, leveraging existing ABAP expertise, and delivering benefits such as harmonized user experience, built-in product standard compliance, and simplified lifecycle management and operations out of the box. To further support this process, SAP offers the open-source ABAP Partner Reference Application as a best-practice resource.

The ABAP Partner Reference Application on SAP-Samples Git repository demonstrates how to design, build, and operate multi-tenant side-by-side applications using ABAP Cloud practices while following SAP’s recommended development approaches. The ABAP Partner Reference Application provides developers and technical architects with standard patterns, modular code, and documented guidance for building robust, multi-tenant ABAP applications on SAP BTP, fully integrated with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. It guides partners on designing, deploying, and extending ABAP solutions. It provides a blueprint for building scalable, multi-tenant apps that extend and integrate with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

 

What is the ABAP Partner Reference Application?

The ABAP Partner Reference Application (APRA) is a sample implementation that provides practical examples, such as the Music Festival Manager. It shows partners how to:

  • Build extensions on SAP BTP ABAP Cloud.
  • Integrate seamlessly with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  • Handle critical multi-tenant aspects such as tenant provisioning, onboarding, and isolation.
  • Follow SAP’s ABAP Cloud and Restful ABAP Programming Model (RAP) guidelines.

In short, it’s a real-world blueprint for partners who need a reference starting point.

Key Capabilities Highlighted

  • Multi-tenancy design: APRA showcases how to build applications that serve multiple tenants securely while keeping data isolated.
  • Tenant lifecycle management: Includes practical examples of provisioning and onboarding processes.
  • Integration patterns: Demonstrates how ABAP applications can consume SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition APIs side by side, extending core business logic without modification.
  • Best practices in ABAP Cloud: Clean-core extensions, RAP-based services, and modular design patterns are applied throughout

Why It Matters for Partners

For partners building SAP-certified solutions, alignment with ABAP Cloud principles is no longer optional. APRA offers more than just example code: it provides implementation guidance to ensure solutions are cloud-ready, scalable, and compliant. By studying and adapting the repository, partners save time, reduce uncertainty, and can fast-track their certification and deployment processes.

  • The repository demonstrates and aligns with SAP clean-core architecture and RAP best practices, enabling maintainable, upgrade-safe solutions. Along with modularization, helping partners build solutions that are scalable, maintainable, and compliant with SAP’s cloud-first best practices.
  • It provides real-world samples for rapid development of side-by-side extensions in the SAP BTP ABAP environment.
  • It demonstrates end-to-end flows: business object modelling, onboarding and provisioning, secure multi-tenancy, and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition API integration. It includes example business objects, tenant-specific onboarding logic, and detailed sample integrations with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition APIs, serving as ready-to-adapt templates for real-world enterprise scenarios.
  • Each step—from tenant lifecycle management to extending SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition functionality using side-by-side applications—is implemented with guidance notes and sample ABAP artifacts, making cloud development approachable for teams at any skill level.
  • Multi-Tenancy Patterns: Learn how to isolate data and processes by tenant, automate provisioning, and secure user access using SAP BTP role collections and dedicated onboarding flows.
  • Integration Points: Discover how to consume core APIs, events, and data from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition while preserving ERP clean core, using recommended SAP BTP services for authentication, navigation, and extensibility.
  • RAP and ABAP Cloud Usage: Access sample RAP service definitions and back-end logic that illustrate SAP’s latest cloud-based application paradigms, making it straightforward to adopt modern development models.

 Getting Started / How to Use the Repository

The repository is publicly available on GitHub and welcomes exploration. Developers can:

  • Import the Music Festival Manager application from your abapGit repository into your ABAP environment in ADT, browse the artifacts, and review the README for instructions on deployment and configuration to start with ready-to-run examples or tutorials.
  • Follow the incremental development guides in the main branch to build up your own ABAP partner app using the same best practices. Follow examples for multi-tenant design, onboarding, and integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  • Analyze business object definitions, RAP service implementations, and onboarding/integration logic to adapt for your own solution. Use the sample reference application as templates for partner apps, adapting the RAP artifacts and onboarding logic for your business scenario and leverage the documented guidance to use APRA as a starting template for your own solutions.

Inside the Repository: Packages and Artifacts

  • The repository is organized to guide developers through building a core ABAP application, then evolving it into a multi-tenant solution.
  • Artifacts are grouped by application logic (business objects), onboarding flows, integration APIs, and service definitions that illustrate SAP’s recommended RAP approach.
  • The samples Music Festival Manager and Poetry Slam Manager demonstrate business object modeling, UI integration, and tenant isolation in real-world use cases.

 How the Repository Accelerates Partner Solutions

  • Partners can reuse packages, study onboarding approaches, and adapt integration modules directly for their own certified offerings—streamlining time to market and improving solution quality.
  • Step-by-step documentation, real code, and sample data flows empower developers to master multi-tenant patterns and extend SAP Cloud systems with confidence.
  • The repository acts as a knowledge base and starter kit for enterprise ABAP cloud projects, bridging theory and practical implementation for SAP’s partner ecosystem.

By exploring this repository, developers and architects gain hands-on experience with the foundations of multi-tenant architecture, SAP BTP-managed security, and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition integration—directly addressing the needs of modern cloud-native SAP applications.

For partners, the repository turns cloud-native theory into practice. Get hands on with SAP BTP ABAP Cloud, accelerate certified solution development, and leverage proven patterns for multi-tenant extensions—all with guided help from SAP’s own reference implementation.

entry.title: Switching to Spaces and Pages Experience Sharing – Changing Page Tile Colors on My Home Page
entry.content:
Introduction

It has been a while since I touched the topic of Spaces and Pages in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Today I am going to continue my series on Spaces and Pages – Changing Page Tile Colors.

Recently one user raised a question:  In the News and Pages section of My Home page, those page tiles were colorful. However, after the 2508 upgrade, they became mono color.  I am going to explain what happened and the steps to bring back the colors and transport this UI change to the Test and Production tenants in a 3 System Landscape.

 

Background

The user sees two different sets of Page Tiles below, one is the mono color after 2508 Upgrade, and another one is the colorful tiles before upgrade in the Starter System which you usually don’t upgrade.

 Mono Color Page Tiles on a 2508 System

 Colorful Tiles on a Starter System (Prior to 2508 Release)

When we talk about these Page Tile colors, a few things need to keep in mind:

  • When a system is delivered or upgraded, the original color is set by the developers. The original color could be gray as shown above if nobody changes it.
  • System administrator can change the colors of these Page Tiles. This color change impacts to all users.  Individual users cannot change the Page Tile color.
  • The color change is part of Key User UI Adaptation effort.

In the next section, I am going to detail the steps to change the Page Tile colors.

 

Steps to Change Page Tile Color

Below figure is my News and Pages section in the Dev tenant.  There are six Page Tiles, only one tile “Customers and Products” has a default gray color.  The remaining five tiles are all colorful.

Six Page Tiles in News and Pages Section

 To Change the title color, we will take the Key User UI Adaptation route.  You can see some explanations in SAP Help Portal, Adapting the UI.

You go to the User Action Menu, select Adapt UI.  Click on the OK button when you see an Info message pop-up: “You have personalized the app or there are public views.  The app is reloading without these changes”.  It might take a few more seconds until you see the below figure which has “UI Adaptation – Navigation – Visualization” in the Title Bar. 

Note 1: At current 2508 release, the UI Adaptation Tool is still not 100% compatible with the Fiori Launchpad. So, you might have to click on “Adapt UI” user menu for the 2nd time to enter the UI Adaptation Tool. This situation will improve in a later release.

Note 2: The pop-up message means for My Home page, there are already changes made by users. The system is going to bring up the app with different versions.

Note 3: The Version History is working, but not robust yet. If you switch to an old version, try to refresh the screen  in your web browser to bring the setting from the server to the frontend. I will talk about it  more later.

Now you click on the right mouse button, the pop-up button Personalize My Home shows up.

UI Adaptation Mode

 Clicking on Personalize My Home button, My Home Settings window pops up. Then expand News and Pages menu in My Home Settings window. Now Edit News and Pages window pops up.

My Home Settings Window

 Expanding the Spaces and Pages menu, you get the Edit Pages window. Here you can scroll up and down in the left panel titled Spaces and Pages to find the page tile you are interested in. For example, I find the Space Internal Sales, Page Sales Processing. By selecting this page, I can change its tile color to one of 10 available colors shown on the right hand side.

Change the Color of a Page Tile

 You might notice that Internal Sales Overview Page Tile has a green color in My Home page, but it shows the gray color on the list. That’s because the developers changed the tile color before its release, the original color (not the default color) is green. The gray color in the list indicates it is still the original color, not touched by the Key User; it could be red or green; or even gray like Page Customers and Products, since the developers leave the default color there as the original color.

After you select the color, click the Close button in the Edit Pages window.  Then click the Save button in the My Home Settings button.

When you come back to the UI Adaptation window, you notice the Sales Processing tile has changed the color.  Also, there is a Draft text in the Version History area.  By expanding the Version History, you can see the entire history of this UI Adaptation.  My current version is still in Draft state, Unpublished. 

Draft State of UI Adaptation

 If you cannot make the final decision on your change, you can save your Draft by clicking the Save button on the right-hand side in the title bar. Keep in mind that other Key Users can edit your draft version change as well. It creates an opportunity to the team work.

Next step of changing the color of a tile is to Activate it by clicking on the button to the right.

The Activation Button of the UI Adaptation Tool

A new window Activate New Version pops up. Try to give a meaningful title and easy for you to find it later in the Version History. I enter “Change color of Sales Processing tile”.  Then, hit the Confirm button.

Give a Name to the New Version

 Now the Version History text changed from “Draft” to “Change color of Sales Processing tile” in green and a Truck icon appears. A new version is born.  You use the Truck icon to publish this UI Adaptation so that all end users can use it.  In addition, you can export this UI Adaptation to your Test and Production tenants.

The Publish Button of the UI Adaptation Tool

After the publication, hit the X button on the right of the UI Adaptation Tool Bar to exit from the tool. Then another pop-up window shows.  It basically tells you that the screen will be refreshed to load your latest version.

Info Pop-Up Window “App Requires Reload”

 

Switch Back to Old Color

Sometimes we need to reverse our work, for example, some end users don’t like the changes we made. This is possible.

To do this, you select an older version from the Version History dropdown list. Refresh the screen to see exactly what old color is! Otherwise, you still see the latest version.  In my example, I selected the very original version called "Original App". Now the Page Tile Sales Processing is changed back to its original color of gray.

Bring back the Original Color

 A little different from our normal understanding, we need to create a new version based on the old version, not just reactivate an old version. Only the version at the top of the Version History can be active, and you cannot move up an old version to the top.  So, when you click on the Activate New Version button, a Reactivate Version window pops up.

Enter Text for Reactivate Version

 Check the Version History, a new version Reverse to Original App is there.  I still need to publish it so that all end users can use it.

The Version History Dropdown List

 

Transport Your Change to the Test and Production Tenants

I have written a blog on Transport Your Spaces and Pages Configurations in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud 3-System Landscape Systems.  It explains all the details of creating and delivering a transport.

After I create a new Software Collection called Page Tile Adaptation, I need to add content to it by clicking the Add Item button. 

Software Collection Page Tile Adaptation

 When you search which content to be added to your UI Adaptation Export Collection, use the filter Type “UI Flexibility: Views and Changes (UIFLEX_CD)”, you should be able to find your content.

Set Filter Type as “UI Flexibility: Views and Changes (UIFLEX_CD)”

 If you make several changes to this Page Tile as I did in this blog, i.e., assigning a color, then reverse it back to the original color, there is only one content item S/4HANA Product Home.

Add an UI Adaptation Content to an Export Software Collection

 After adding the content to the Software Collection, I click on the Inventory button to find out what’s inside.

Add Content Item S/4HANA Product Home to the Software Collection Page Tile Adaptation

The Inventory button opens a Change History of the Content Item S/4HANA Product Home.  Within two days of writing this blog, I made changes four times until assigning this collection to the Software Collection Page Tile Adaptation.

List of All Changes Made to the Content Item S/4HANA Product Home

 

Conclusion

As an administrator, you can change the color of the Page Tiles in My Home page for all users by using the Key User UI Adaptation tool.  You can bring the colorful page tiles back to your My Home page.

 

References

  • Transport Your Spaces and Pages Configurations in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud 3-System Landscape Systems
  • Switching to Spaces and Pages Experience Sharing – My Three Best Practices of Using Spaces and Pages
  • Switching to Spaces and Pages Experience Sharing - Deploying Spaces and Pages Best Practices
  • Switching to Spaces and Pages Experience Sharing - Assigning Predefined S&P to Your Own Biz Roles
  • Switching to Spaces and Pages Experience Sharing - Using Display Security Audit Log Fiori App

entry.title: Test Data Conversion, the accelerator: scaling smart
entry.content:
In our Data Migration for Test Environment Validation in ... - SAP Community Blog, we explored Test Data Conversion (TDC) and Test Data Refresh (TDR), the potential pathways for test system readiness as part of the 3 SL post-conversion activity. We have also seen the unique value added by both the services. If you're seeking deeper insight into Test Data Conversion (TDC), you're in the right place. In this blog we will see a comprehensive overview of TDC, purpose, and value added by TDC.  

Customer satisfaction is the cornerstone of any business. To ensure a seamless transition into 3 SL conversion, TDC is being offered as a one-time complimentary service to all the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 3 SL conversion customers by SAP. 

Before we delve into the full scope and benefits of TDC, Let’s have an understanding on the key prerequisites for TDC implementation. 

TDC Pre-requisites: 

To ensure a seamless and efficient data transfer during the TDC enablement process, below key prerequisites must be fulfilled at the system level: 

  1. Uniform Software Release Across all tenants: 
    • All Tenants must operate on the same software release configuration. 
    • This consistency helps eliminate system discrepancies and ensures reliable data flow. 
  2. System Configuration Maintenance 
    • A well-maintained System configuration is essential for seamless TDC execution. 
    • It supports system stability there by reduces integration friction.  
  3. Content Version Alignment 
    • All tenants should be in the same content version release. 
    • Version mismatches can lead to errors during data transfer and could lead to incomplete data mapping.  
  4. Extension Readiness 
    • Ensure all relevant extensions are active and configured with the latest updates. 
    • The Handle Your Extensions app will come handy to verify and manage extensions efficiently. 
  5. Clean Development Transport Queue 
    • Confirm that there are no open transports in the development queue. 
    • The transport queue should be clean to avoid data inconsistency or conflicts. 

Note:  if you need help with the first three prerequisites, The conversion team will help you to validate and maintain the necessary configurations across tenants. This simplifies the process and ensures readiness for TDC onboarding. 

TDC: Enabling Seamless Data Transition for tenant post-conversion 

The TDC service offers a powerful solution for transferring reliable data from the development tenant to the test tenant. It supports the migration of: 

  • Master Data 
  • Transactional Data 
  • Historical Test Data 
  • System Configurations (e.g., Output Management and others) 

 By this, TDC will not only take care of data, but also help in setting up certain configurations thereby reduces manual setup efforts and accelerate system readiness process. One of the critical components in system setup is the Output Management Configuration. TDC streamlines this process by automatically transferring output management configuration data from the development tenant to the new test tenant. In addition to configuration data, TDC also migrates all available test automation assets, ensuring that testing frameworks and scripts are ready to resume at the earliest. 

One of the key concerns during data migration is data privacy. TDC service offers depersonalization as an optional feature, which ensures sensitive information (Workforce data is out of scope) is anonymized during the transfer process. 

Note: Depersonalization is a broad and critical topic. While this blog focuses on understanding TDC, reference links will be provided below for those who wish to explore depersonalization in detail. 

Once the data migration via TDC is complete, the system reaches a near-ready state, as a next step initiate Rewiring of Applications as a Post migration step to ensure the alignment of applications with the new test tenant. This step ensures seamless integration with applications and functionality across the system landscape. 

Note: Rewiring of apps is beyond the scope of this blog. Kindly refer to SAP help page for those who wish to explore Rewiring of apps in more detail. 

With consistent and complete data in place and successful rewiring of apps, the test tenant becomes fully operational. This marks the transition of test tenant from setup to active usage. All available test automation scripts from the development tenant can now be resumed. This helps to validate system integrity, confirm readiness, and ensure smooth performance post conversion. 

Conclusion: 

In this Blog, we’ve explored the pre-requisite, scope of TDC. We've also seen how TDC significantly reducing manual effort and saving time during the 3 SL post conversion process. 

We hope this has provided you with a comprehensive and clear understanding of TDC, its benefits, and its role in enabling a smoother transition to the new Test tenant.

Definition :  The Custom Analytical Queries app is a tool used for reporting and analysis.

This tool transforms and organizes raw data delivered from business documents into a meaningful grid. It abstracts the process of writing structured queries so that you don’t have to understand the query language or the technical details.

Custom Analytical Queries provides the fields required to design a query. You select the required fields and set filters for your query. You can add restricted measures, calculated measures, and preview the query results. The various options in Custom Analytical Queries and the task that you can perform using the options are as follows:

  • Search: Use to search an existing query.

  • New: Use to create a query.

  • Copy: Use to create queries from predefined SAP queries or from packages that you do not have permissions.

  • Adding Dimensions and Measures from the Data Source: Use to add a field from a data source to define a query or to remove a field from the query.

( Definition referred From :  Custom Analytical Queries - SAP Doc )

In my words , Custom analytical queries are a tool for dynamic representation of data in rows and columns which provide meaningful insights , business intelligence and summarization of data in a higher to lower drilldown model with aggregations and segregations .

( Literally I'm too bad in defining things in my own words )

Now lets Fall back to our scenario , I am creating an Analytical query with the name Analytical_Q2 and data source  I_ACCOUNTINGDOCUMENTJOURNAL , one of SAP released / Standard CDS views.

and you will be on the next screen after clicking OK .

You will be in the first tab General , 

in the General tab under properties , you can :

  • add your Label 
  •  Name and Data source will be displayed 
  • Set the Zero suppression

Under the Additional Properties , you can :

  •  Processing effort for the query , Low / Medium / High 
  • Set Run Time extensibility 

On the top right corner you can see your status of the Query (Draft / Saved / published )

On the bottom right you can see buttons for , Saving Draft / Publishing / Previewing 

 

Moving to the Next Tab  Field selection : 

You can see all your fields available in the Data source here . Check the selection check box for fields you will be needing in the query . 

After selecting the check box you can see that most of the fields fell in to the Free axis position but some of them have automatically fallen to the Measure category . Mostly the fields with amount , quantity or marked as measure in the data source fall to this category. 

If you look closely to the field list , you can see the type of field . 

  • if a field is having  symbol , this is a dimension and could be placed in the ROW / Column axis of the report / Query.
  • if a field is having  symbol , this is a measure and could be placed in the COLUMN axis of the report / Query.
  • if a field is having  symbol , this is a date field and could be placed in ROW / Column axis of the report / Query.

In data analysis, dimensions are qualitative, descriptive fields (like names, dates, or categories) that provide context and "slice" data, answering "who," "what," "when," and "where". Measures are quantitative, numerical fields (like sales, quantities, or profits) that you calculate or aggregate to answer "how much" or "how many". The core difference is that dimensions provide the descriptive context, while measures provide the numerical values to analyze within that context. 

Dimensions
Purpose: To provide context, segment, and describe data.
Data Type: Qualitative, categorical, or descriptive data.
Examples:
Product names, customer IDs, region, date.
Information like "who," "what," "where," and "when".
Measures
Purpose: To be calculated and aggregated, such as sums or averages, to provide quantifiable insights. 
Data Type: Quantitative, numerical, and measurable data. 
Examples: 
Sales, profit, quantity, price, and temperature. 
Information that answers "how much" or "how many". 
 
Moving to the Next Tab Display :
Now you can move the fields to your desired axis , Row / Column. To do that you can either select the field and use the up , down button in the table to move the fields and place it in order . Or you can also use the Axis field in the options area and place the field in different Axis.
I have adjusted the axis in the following order: 
Now lets focus the main table with fields from left ,
  • you will see Remove column with x button to remove the field from the selection.
  • Filter column to set the Filed as a filter ( We will look at the Filter in the next section or tab).
  • Display column to hide / show the field in output. 
  • Name , label and Type as seen earlier and also a row wise hierarchy  separator to show the fields category or placement.
 
Now lets Save our Query and have a Preview :
We will consider this preview for comparing with changes we are going to next.
Now lets select a field in the row category and look at the available properties (Right Pane) . 

 

  • Use the Override Label to change the default Label :
  • Display option to set field visible .
  • Display result Option to enable Total / Grand total row based on this field .
  • Dimension format to display either the Key  / text / Key and text / text and Key  value of the Field , Applicable in case of fields with Key and value pair , eg : Country , currency , company code etc 
  • Sorting to set the sorting for the Field , Ascending / descending . 
  • Axis is to place the field at desired axis (Row / Column).
  • Include Unbooked data option to show values with this field as empty but others having data .
 
Now lets look at a Measure and its Properties :
  • Use the Override Label to change the default Label :
  • Display option to set field visible .
  • Decimals option to define the number of decimal places needed.
  • Scaling option to set the level of scaling .
  • Reverse sign to reverse the sign of value .
  • Use  the hierarchy  Part to set the Hierarchy of the field if needed.
  • Collapsed to set the view to collapsed .
  • Enable hierarchy to enable hierarchy , Collapsed will only work if hierarchy is set . 
  • Parent option to set the parent node of the current field in the hierarchy.
 
Now after making some changes let me show the preview again :
Moving to the Next Tab Filters :
 
Here lets select a Row / Dimension and set the Filter values , Only dimensions are allowed as filters .
 
  • You can set No filter for a field , which will be default .
  • Fixed Filter with values to
    • include and exclude.
  • User Input Values Filter with
    • selection type  Single / Interval
    • Multiple selection
    • Mandatory Option
    • Variable sequence
    • Default value
  • Derivation Functions with 
    • Lookup entity (Search help )
    • Hidden 
    • Mandatory

Now after making some changes let me show the preview again :

 

Now we have covered almost all the options in all the tabs , but we haven't explored the ADD button in the Display tab . 

This option lets you add :

  • Add Restricted Measure
  • Add Calculated Measure
  • Add Converted Measure
  • Add Counter
  • Add User Input Filter
  • Add Characteristic Structure Element

REQUEST DESCRIPTION

  • How to unlock the combined value of invoice and payment data in the ERP alongside the cash and financial data held by banks?

Morgan bank services embedded in ERP processes.

  • Organizations operating on J.P. Morgan Access, with support for multi-bank reporting across non–J.P. Morgan DDAs

This collaboration meets clients where they are simplifying connectivity while strengthening control and visibility at the same time, and accelerating access to new banking innovations, all embedded in SAP ERP processes.

entry.title: Get & Stay Secure in the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition with the SAP EarlyWatch Alert Security Chapter
entry.content:
When moving to the public cloud with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP is taking care of many security relates topics as cloud provider. However, in order to stay secure, customers are still responsible for the mitigation of risks such as business or technical users having critical authorizations.

Here, the SAP EarlyWatch Alert report in SAP for Me comes into play as it gives you insights into security risks in the chapter "Security (Public Cloud)". This chapter gives you insights and alerts you on the following topics:

  • Identity and Access Management - get additional information and resources on how to use Identity and Access Management (IAM) to establish, tailor, and monitor business roles to business needs and requirements
  • Deprecated Business Catalogs - revise deprecated business catalogs still in use that might be removed in future releases
  • Business Users Assigned to Many Business Roles - get alerted when business users have many business roles assigned, deviating from the best practice of only one per business user
  • Assignment of users to Business Role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR - check for usage of this role resulting in segregation of duties (SoD) conflicts as it is intended only for the initial configuration of a system
  • Use of Read/Write Unrestricted - be alerted on business roles having unrestricted write, read and value help access
  • Business Catalog Assignments - be warned about critical assignments of business catalogs to your business users
  • Communication (Inbound/Outbound) - find customer managed communication arrangements without certificate-based authentication using only basic authentication
  • Upcoming Certificate Expiration - early warning for certificates managed by the customer that will expire within the next 90 days

You can find more details on each of these chapters below or by directly accessing the SAP EarlyWatch Alert report* for your systems in SAP for Me. 

* an authorized users is needed to access this applicaion, refer to this SAP Support page on how to get access.

 

Identity and Access Management

Identity and Access Management (IAM) ensures that all business users within an organization have defined and managed business roles. With IAM, organizations can establish, tailor, and monitor business roles to business needs and requirements. There are several relevant applications available for managing IAM in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

The SAP EarlyWatch Alert provides an overview of relevant information and resources to enable the effective use of IAM.

 

Deprecated Business Catalogs

It is important to adapt existing Business Catalogs and Business Roles resulting from the addition of new scope items or a release upgrade. In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Business Catalogs are periodically revised. Some Business Catalogs will be deprecated and replaced by new ones. The deprecated Business Catalogs in the system may be removed by SAP at the time of a release after it has been declared as deprecated, so it is important to review the deprecated Business Catalogs after each release along with new scope items and make the necessary changes as soon as possible.

In this chapter, a list of deprecated business catalogs in use in the system and information how to handle this is provided.

 

Business Users Assigned to Many Business Roles

SAP best practice is to assign only one business role to a business user. Each business role must represent a workplace and business roles should be created from scratch using the workplace approach.  For production, it is strongly recommended to build production roles manually to ensure compliance with external and internal compliance rules for access.

In the this chapter, the system is checked for users that have multiple business roles assigned.

 

Assignment of users to Business Role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR

The role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR is predefined by SAP and is intended only for the initial configuration of a system. Usage of this role in production does not correspond to SAP recommendations and may lead to compliance issues.

The system is checked for the usage of this role in this chapter to alert on the potential risk that comes along with using it.

 

Use of Read/Write Unrestricted

Using unrestricted fields in the maintenance of business roles allow users to have global data access, SAP best practices recommend to carefully review which users need to have restricted data access and maintain the access appropriately, e.g. ensuring employees only have access to data belonging to their sales organization.

This chapter informs about the number of busines roles with unrestricted write, read or value help access.

Use of Read/Write Unrestricted Result Table Example

 

Business Catalog Assignments

Business catalogs contain a bundle of privileges needed for accessing an app or features that are then assigned to users via business roles. This section checks for selected critical business catalogs and their assignment to business roles and users and rates this according to the valuationrules from SAP Note 863362. In case any critical business catalogs are assigned, additional details are presented as sub-chapters.

Business Catalog Assignments Overview Table Example

 

Communication (Inbound/Outbound)

It is recommended that certificate-based communication is used for technical users involved in inbound/outbound communication when possible. Usually, it is easier to detect if a certificate is compromised than detect if a password has been compromised. This chapter identifies whether any customer managed communication arrangements do not use certificate-based authenticate and provides a list of them.

 

Upcoming Certificate Expiration

In case there are any certificates where their expiration date is coming up in the next 90 days, they will be listed in this chapter to notify about this early on.

 

 

Do you want to learn more on how to find and use the security relevant content in the SAP EarlyWatch Alert Workspace? Then check out this blog for more information.

Stay tuned for more content regarding Security in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition systems to be added to the SAP EarlyWatch Alert! 🚀

entry.title: A Practical Guide to Cost Center APIs in SAP S/4HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Introduction

When working with cost center master data in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, we often encounter the need to use different APIs. Depending on the scenario, there can be several options available to integrate, replicate, or maintain cost center data.

At first glance, it may seem straightforward to simply use an API. However, the reality is more complex. cost center provides multiple API options, each designed with its own strengths, limitations, and typical use cases.

This blog post aims to bring more clarity by walking through the different API options available for cost center in the public cloud context. We will start by explaining some core concepts, such as the difference between synchronous and asynchronous APIs, and how to think about inbound and outbound APIs. Later, we will look into the individual technologies and provide guidance on how to choose the right API for your use case.

 

Synchronous vs. Asynchronous APIs

One of the most fundamental distinctions when talking about APIs is whether they are synchronous or asynchronous.

  • Synchronous APIs:
    A synchronous API works like a phone call. You “dial” the API, send a request, and wait for the response. You know immediately whether the operation succeeded or failed. This approach is great for real-time validation, single record maintenance, and interactive applications.
  • Asynchronous APIs:
    An asynchronous API is more like sending a letter or an email. You send the request, and the system processes it in the background. The response may come later, often through a callback, message, or event. This approach is better suited for bulk operations, replication, or integrations where immediate feedback is not required.

In practice, you will often integrate APIs into workflows. A useful guideline is to stick to one type of API in your workflow. Mixing synchronous and asynchronous calls can introduce complexity, especially if you need to coordinate responses.

For example:

  • Starting with an asynchronous request and then immediately relying on a synchronous call without checking status may fail because the data is not yet processed.
  • If you must combine them, always build in the right checks: confirm the asynchronous process is complete before moving to the synchronous step.

Examples: How to work with synchronous/asynchronous APIs

  • If your process needs an instant response, such as validation or single master data change — go for synchronous.
  • If your process deals with large volumes or can wait for processing — asynchronous is usually more efficient.

 

Inbound vs. Outbound APIs

Another useful way of categorizing APIs is to look at whether they are inbound or outbound:

  • Inbound APIs: These are used when an external system wants to send data to an SAP S/4HANA system. In the cost center context, this could mean creating, updating, or deleting cost center master data from an external application.
  • Outbound APIs: These are used when an SAP S/4HANA system sends data or events to an external system. In other words, these APIs “push” information out.

 

Technologies

Working with cost center master data comes with different integration needs, and SAP offers a variety of API technologies to meet them. Each option is designed for specific scenarios and scope items, so choosing the right API depends on your particular requirements. In the sections below, we provide an overview of the key technologies available in SAP S/4HANA Cloud and how they are typically used.

OData V4:

The Cost Center OData V4 service allows you to create, read, update, and delete cost center master data directly in your system. Since it is an inbound, synchronous API, it is designed for real-time interactions where you need immediate feedback on your changes. The service is built on the RESTful ABAP Programming Model (RAP), which ensures it follows modern development principles and supports extensibility. This means you can adapt the data model and business logic to meet your specific requirements without losing compatibility during system upgrades. Typical scenarios for using this API include creating or updating cost centers from external applications or interactive user interfaces, where instant validation and confirmation are important.

🔗 OData V4 cost center API on API Hub

Business Object Extensibility (Steampunk API)

For developers working on SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform), the cost center business object  Steampunk APIs provide another way to interact with cost center master data. These APIs are also inbound and synchronous, making them suitable for real-time updates. 

🔗Steampunk API on API Hub

OData V2 Read APIs

In some cases, you only need read-only access to cost center data.  OData V2 Read APIs  (A2X services ) provide synchronous access to this information, enabling external systems to retrieve data in real time without modifying it. This is useful for reporting, monitoring, or any scenarios where up-to-date cost center information is required for external applications.

🔗OData V2 Read cost center API on API Hub

Business Events

When your goal is to react to changes rather than actively pull data, Business Events are the way to go. These are outbound, meaning S/4HANA pushes notifications to subscribing systems whenever a relevant change occurs. By subscribing to cost center events, a workflow or external application can respond immediately, for example by fetching updated details or triggering additional processes. This event-driven approach is particularly useful for keeping external systems in sync with S/4HANA or automating business processes based on changes in master data.

🔗 Cost center Business Events on API Hub

SOAP API

As the name suggests, this API transfers the request via SOAP protocol. SOAP API CostCentreReplicationBulkRequest_In is an inbound, asynchronous API that can be used for cost center replication into your S/4HANA system. As it is based on asynchronous processing, it is suitable for changes that do not require immediate response. Usage of SOAP APIs in workflows is generally not advised, unless they perform the final operation or an operation that is not prerequisite for a follow-up step.

 🔗 SOAP cost center API on API Hub 

 

How to choose an API that suits you best

While there are many scenarios where you can use cost center APIs. This little breakdown gives you an idea of which technology to use for each case. Whiie various APIs can support certain scenarios, we highlight the ones that offer the best capabilities for the given task.

 

Combining different APIs in a single workflow

Earlier, we have outlined the importance of taking caution when working with different technologies in a single workflow. This is especially true if a synchronous API and an asynchronous API coexist in the same stack. Let’s explore possible scenarios and their potential challenges.

Combining Synchronous and Asynchronous APIs

There are multiple systems that can carry out cost center changes. Each system, when the change or creation happens, sends a request to the consolidation system that collects all changes from all systems in the landscape and consolidates them. Periodically, this system returns the consolidated data to the source systems for replication and sends them also to receiver systems.

  • If this is done on a time basis, for example, the replication is triggered every midnight, there is no significance whether the replication is carried out synchronously or asynchronously.
  • But if there is a condition in place, for example when the replication is triggered after every change request, then the importance of choosing the right technology is essential.

Asynchronous APIs and Their Challenges

If you send a change request via a SOAP API (asynchronous), you would get an immediate response of HTTP status 200, which simply means that the request was accepted, not that the processing is complete. This is often confused as a response to the request being carried out, which is not exactly true. The request was only accepted and (apart from subscription to business event), there is no further notification of a successful completion. It’s important to keep in mind this distinction:

  • If you misinterpret the initial HTTP response as confirmation of successful processing and use it as a trigger for the replication, you could potentially replicate outdated data, as carrying out the change takes time and is dependent on system resources available.
  • It is also unreliable to choose an arbitrary wait time and then follow up with replication.

The only way to ensure proper synchronization is to trigger an additional GET request, verifying you have the expected data in the system. Or you can avoid this hassle by simply carrying out a synchronous request via OData API. Successful response in a synchronous API means that the request is completed in full and the data is processed and persisted. This can safely serve as a trigger condition for your further processing.

Combining APIs and Business Events

Let’s describe a different scenario where a combination of a business event and an OData API provide a more fluid and efficient integration of a simple workflow. When a cost center is changed in a system, the system implicitly triggers a business event. If there is a listener active, other system can receive this signal with a payload and act according to the desired logic. The payload only consists of the key fields, so when the system recognizes this data as necessary for further processing, it may send an OData GET request to the provider system to retrieve the full data set and persist changes.

 

Conclusion

This post provides a clear overview of the various APIs available for managing cost center master data in SAP S/4HANA Cloud. By understanding the differences between synchronous and asynchronous APIs, inbound and outbound communication, and the specific applications of technologies like OData V4, SOAP, and Business Events, you can choose the most suitable option for your integration needs. Using the right API technology thoughtfully can simplify workflows, ensure data accuracy, and optimize system efficiency. With these insights, you are well-prepared to make the most of the capabilities each API offers while avoiding challenges in complex integrations.

entry.title: Next Generation Just-In-Time, Supply to Customer
entry.content:
The Next Generation JIT Processing solution is now available in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (Supply to Customer).

 JIT Supply to Customer(S2C) allows you to run just-in-time process with your customer for products delivered from stock or manufactured based on JIT requests. You can receive and process delivery schedules with reference to JIT sales scheduling agreements for planning and production purposes and receive summarized or sequenced JIT calls for shipping purposes. The Next Generation JIT S2C provide bellow business value:

  • Supports the basic business process for just-in-time supply
  • Provides efficiency and transparency in processing
  • Helps process the supply efficiently
  • Flexibility through configuration and extensibility

Let’s take the business of automobile industry as an example, JIT S2C solution will be used on the supply business between Component Manufacturer and Vehicle Manufacturer.

There are two types of JIT Call: Summarized JIT Call and Sequenced JIT Call.

Summarized JIT Call is quantity-based or container-based call-offs without vehicle reference.

Sequenced JIT Call is Order-based requests for supply in sequence of production with Vehicle-specific (reference to VIN/production number).

Let’s focus on Sequenced JIT Call and deep dive further.

From the above lifecycle figure of the Sequenced JIT Calls, you can see that:

  • We start the process from manage customer request by creating Customer JIT Calls. Most of the time JIT Calls will be created via EDI, but manually creating JIT Calls also be supported.
  • If you supply to customer with production, you release JIT Calls to production and confirm production with related goods movements posted.
  • After the manufactured products been received to stock, you pack the products and create outbound deliveries. Post goods issue to the outbound deliveries.
  • Create and process billing document from customer.

We support Monitoring JIT Calls by Internal Processing Status like below. You can easily figure out how many JIT Calls are there and which status they are in.

Overall, next-generation JIT processing in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition provides a robust framework for managing complex supply chain operations, offering significant advantages in terms of efficiency, flexibility, and transparency.
